name: SmartRisk Agent™ and Risk Score Guide
title: SmartRisk Agent™ and Risk Score Guide
body:
Coming soon: On December 15, we’ll update the benchmarks for the Low, Medium, High, and Critical risk levels in the Risk Score available range based on data analysis across all customers. Your actual Risk Score won't change, but its risk level label may shift to reflect our new benchmarks better.

Our SmartRisk Agent™ feature provides more in-depth analysis with tailored recommendations to help you better understand your organization’s security strengths and weaknesses. You can use SmartRisk Agent™ to learn which users may be more vulnerable to phishing attacks and review the effectiveness of your security awareness training program.

Note:Data for our SmartRisk Agent™ is available from February 2024 onwards.

SmartRisk Agent™ assigns dynamic Risk Scores to your users, groups, and organization. You can use these Risk Scores to make data-driven decisions for your organization's security.

KnowBe4 records a unique Risk Score for your users, groups, and organization. Your Risk Score is calculated using risk factors from various security types, which are our groupings for risk factors. Risk factors include specific events that can be positive, such as reporting a phishing email with the Phish Alert Button (PAB), or negative, such as clicking a phishing link.

Risk Scores increase when users fail phishing tests, engage in risky behaviors, or have their training completion statuses expire. Conversely, users can improve their scores by reporting phishing emails via the PAB and completing all assigned training modules.

It’s important to remember that:

  • Risk Scores update automatically based on tracked behaviors—no manual adjustments are possible
  • Organizational factors like missing security products can also influence scores

For more technical information about Risk Score and commonly asked questions and answers, see our FAQ: SmartRisk Agent™ and Risk Score Guide.

Depending on your report type, you can filter your Risk Score Reports by Date Range, groups, managers, or users.

On the Manager Risk Score report, you can use the Organization Chart to filter your report by user name or job title. This filter shows user data for all organization levels under the selected managers or job titles. For example, you can search for a specific job title, such as Director or Vice President. You can also select from the two options below:

  • Select Include All Team Members to include the direct and indirect reports of the selected managers in the report.
  • Select Include Selected Manager to include the selected manager in the report.

Available Range

Risk factors from security types inform your organization’s available range. Your available range indicates your level of risk, with one being the least risky and 100 being the most risky.

Your available range for Risk Score is also calculated using the information provided by our products, such as SecurityCoach or PasswordIQ. While having all of our products isn't a requirement for Risk Score, it helps us to provide you with a more accurate available range for your Risk Score. For more information on possible available ranges, see the table below. These ranges are calculated based on products that are enabled and actively used.

Enabled Products and Features Minimum Risk Score Maximum Risk Score
KSAT Training tab 27.7 47.2
KSAT Phishing tab 38.2 45.1
KSAT Training tab and Phishing tab 26.0 52.4
KSAT Training tab, Phishing tab, and Phish Alert Button (PAB) 21.7 55.0
KSAT Training tab, Phishing tab, PAB, and Email Exposure Check (EEC) Pro 20.6 58.2
KSAT Training tab, Phishing tab, PAB, EEC Pro, and PasswordIQ 19.7 60.9
KSAT Training tab, Phishing tab, PAB, EEC Pro, PasswordIQ, and SecurityCoach 10 90
Note:Risk factors from security types where you don't have products are assumed to be risky as user behavior is unknown.

New User Bias

Whenever you add a new user to your console, your organization’s Risk Score will increase for 90 days. During this 90-day period, the new user bias is applied. Any training completions and phishing test results are still recorded and factored into the user's overall risk profile. However, the impact of these positive actions may be less noticeable due to the applied bias.

After 90 days, the new user bias is removed. Then, your organization’s Risk Score will show the entirety of the user's performance, including all training completed and phishing test results from the past 90 days. Users who have completed training and performed well in phishing simulations during their first 90 days will see a more significant drop in their Risk Score once the new user bias is removed.

Security Types

The Security Types widget shows how your Risk Score has changed for each security type. A green arrow indicates that your Risk Score decreased, a red arrow indicates that your Risk Score increased, and a gray line indicates that your Risk Score didn’t change. You can click the arrow to view more details about each security type. For more information, see the screenshot and list below:

  1. Active Factors: This column displays risk factors that are from security types with active products that are enabled and actively used.
  2. Behavior Type: This column indicates if the behavior was risky or secure. Risky behavior increases your Risk Score, while secure behavior decreases your Risk Score.
    Note: Mitigation events also positively impact your Risk Score. Currently, mitigation events include SecurityTips, AIDA Remedial Training completions, and resolved PasswordIQ vulnerability scans.
  3. Source: This column indicates which product contributed to the risk factor.
  4. Points: This column displays the current Risk Score contribution for the selected risk factor as well as the overall trend change in your Risk Score. The overall trend change will be displayed as going up or down from the last recorded Risk Score.
    Note:Expiring risky events may decrease your Risk Score, and expiring secure events may increase your Risk Score. Each risk factor has its own time-to-live (TTL) value, so events only impact your Risk Score for a set amount of time.
  5. Inactive Factors: This column displays risk factors that are from security types that have no products. Since we aren’t receiving data, we set the Risk Score value for these factors.

For more information on each security type and example risk factors, see the table below.

Security Type Description Example Risk Factor
Email Security Email Security reflects risks from a user’s email usage and interactions. Reporting a phishing email with the PAB
Endpoint Security Endpoint Security reflects risks posed by a user’s interaction with their device. Malware detected on a user’s device
Data Security Data Security reflects risks from data that a user shares. Sharing files to an external device
Web Security Web Security reflects risks from a user’s online behavior. Visiting harmful websites
Account Hygiene Account Hygiene reflects a user's overall security awareness related to their accounts. Having a strong password
Compliance Electives Compliance Electives reflect a user’s training completions related to compliance topics. Completing security awareness training related to compliance
Physical Security Physical Security reflects a user’s training completions related to physical security. Tailgating

Risk Score Trend

The Risk Score Trend chart shows the trend of your organization's aggregated Risk Score over the selected date range.

Risk Score Distribution

The Risk Score Distribution chart shows how users in your organization are distributed across different Risk Score ranges for the selected date range.

Riskiest Users

The Riskiest Users chart shows the top ten riskiest users for your selected report and your select date range. A green arrow indicates that your Risk Score decreased, a red arrow indicates that your Risk Score increased, and a gray line indicates that your Risk Score didn’t change. To filter your chart by your safest users, select the Riskiest Users drop-down menu, then select Safest Users.

Riskiest Teams

The Riskiest Teams chart shows the top ten riskiest teams of direct reports for your Manager Risk Score report and your selected date range. A green arrow indicates that your Risk Score decreased, a red arrow indicates that your Risk Score increased, and a gray line indicates that your Risk Score didn’t change. To filter your chart by your safest teams, select the Riskiest Teams drop-down menu, then select Safest Teams.

Riskiest Groups

The Riskiest Groups chart shows the top ten riskiest groups for the selected groups in your Group Risk Score report and your selected date range. A green arrow indicates that your Risk Score decreased, a red arrow indicates that your Risk Score increased, and a gray line indicates that your Risk Score didn’t change. To filter your chart by your safest groups, select the Riskiest Groups drop-down menu, then select Safest Groups.

images.alt:
This UI excerpt displays the header and filtering controls for a reporting interface.

**Header and Context:**
The screen is titled **"Risk Score v2 Reports"**. The active report is specified below this title as **"Manager Risk Score"** (a clickable element with a dropdown chevron).

**Action Controls (Top Right):**
Two buttons are present for report management:
1.  **Export as**: A white, bordered dropdown button.
2.  **Save Report**: A solid dark gray button featuring a bookmark icon.

**Filter Panel:**
A section labeled **"Filters"** contains two primary configuration categories:

1.  **Organization Chart:**
    *   Label includes a tooltip/help icon.
    *   A single search/dropdown input field contains the placeholder text: "Search by manager name or job title..."

2.  **Date Range:**
    *   This category utilizes three sequential dropdown controls:
        *   The first is set to **"Preset Range"**.
        *   The second is set to **"Last 6 Months"**.
        *   The third is set to the timezone **"(GMT-04:00) Eastern Time (US & Canada)"**.
images.context: ude the selected manager in the report.

images.alt:
This dashboard element provides an organizational risk assessment summary, displaying a current score, risk level classification, and actionable recommendations.

**Assessment Summary:**

*   **Risk Classification:** Medium Risk (Large, bold font).
*   **Current Score:** 26.7/100 (Primary numerical display).
*   **Organizational Context:** A supplementary note identifies the scoring boundary: "Your organization's available range is 10.0 - 90.0."

**Graphical Risk Meter:**

A horizontal, color-coded risk meter visualizes the score. The meter is segmented into four color zones representing increasing risk levels: Green (Low Risk), Yellow, Orange, and Red (Critical Risk).

*   **Indicator:** A black, upward-pointing triangle with the value "**26.7**" marks the current score, placing it within the Yellow segment (Medium Risk).
*   **Range Overlay:** A dashed line above the bar visually delineates the organization's available range (10.0–90.0).

**Recommendations Section:**

This section provides specific context and training calls-to-action, separated from the score area by a horizontal rule.

*   **Risk Area Identification:** The primary risk is identified as "Email Security."
*   **Recommendation 1 (Targeted Training):** "We recommend assigning targeted training for this security type." (Includes a blue hyperlink with an external link icon).
*   **Recommendation 2 (Foundational Training):** Addresses the impact of "New employees" and advises assigning a foundational training module.
*   **Supporting Links:**
    *   "Learn more about the new employee bias." (Hyperlink with external link icon).
    *   "Learn more about your available range." (Hyperlink with external link icon).
images.context: g the least risky and 100 being the most risky.

images.alt:
This image displays a section detailing security performance factors, titled **"Security Types."**

**Contextual Summary:**
The primary section focuses on **"Email Security,"** contributing **43.7% of the total score.** The current contribution is **20.1 points towards score,** showing a negative trend of **↓ 0.04 points last 6 months.** A collapse/expand caret (^) is visible next to the score metrics.

**Data Table Structure:**
The data is presented in a sortable table structure with four columns detailing individual security factors:

1.  **Active Factors:** Lists specific user or system activities. This column includes a sort control (up/down arrows) and a tooltip icon (a question mark within a circle). Example factors include "PAB Reporting" and "Simulated Phishing Security Test Failure." "Email Security Training" is displayed as a blue hyperlink with an external link icon.
2.  **Behavior Type:** Classifies the factor's impact, using color-coding:
    *   **Secure** (Green text, e.g., PAB Reporting).
    *   **Risky** (Red text, e.g., Phishing Link Clicked).
3.  **Source:** Identifies the data origin system (e.g., KSAT, SecurityCoach).
4.  **Points:** A numeric field indicating the score value attributed to the factor, ranging from 7.8 down to 0.9 in the displayed data, and includes a sort control.

**Key Data Examples:**
Positive (Secure) factors contributing highly include PAB Reporting (7.8 points) and Email Security Training (6.2 points). Negative (Risky) factors include Phishing Link Clicked (2.6 points) and Malicious Content in Email (1.3 points). Data sources are split between KSAT and SecurityCoach.
images.context: For more information, see the screenshot and list below:

images.alt:
This image displays a subsection of a user interface detailing factors contributing to a security or behavior score.

**Header Section (Blue/White Background):**
*   **Category:** "Physical Security" (Blue text).
*   **Weight:** "4.1% of total score" (Smaller text below category).
*   **Contribution:** "1.9 points towards score" (Blue text, upper right).
*   **Change Status:** "No change last 6 months" (Smaller text below contribution).
*   **UI Element:** A chevron icon pointing upward (collapse/expand toggle).

**Data Table Section:**
The data is presented in a table format with four column headers:
1.  **Inactive Factors** (Includes a sort/filter icon, a black circular question mark icon, and an orange circular icon containing a white 'e').
2.  **Behavior Type**
3.  **Source**
4.  **Points** (Includes a sort/filter icon).

**Row 1 Data Entry:**
*   **Factor:** "Physical Security Training" (Blue hyperlink text with an external link icon).
*   **Behavior Type:** "Secure" (Green text).
*   **Source:** "KSAT".
*   **Points:** "1.9".

A line chart titled **"Trend of Users"** displays the evolution of a "Risk Score" over a time period spanning approximately six months.

**Chart Elements:**
*   **Title:** Trend of Users.
*   **Y-Axis (Vertical):** Labeled **"Risk Score,"** scaled from 30 to 90, with increments of 10 (30, 40, 50, 60, 70, 80, 90). Horizontal grid lines correspond to these major ticks.
*   **X-Axis (Horizontal):** Displays dates ranging from **12/24/2023** to **06/16/2024**. Major ticks include 12/24/2023, 01/28/2024, 03/03/2024, 04/07/2024, 05/12/2024, and 06/16/2024, suggesting approximately monthly intervals.
*   **Data Series:** A single blue line connects circular blue data points, illustrating the Risk Score trend.
*   **Legend:** Located below the X-axis, identifying the series as **"Trend of Users"** (represented by a blue circle and line).
*   **Trend:** The Risk Score initially rises from 12/24/2023 (approx. 64) to a peak around 02/01/2024 (approx. 78), then decreases sharply, reaching a trough around 05/01/2024 (approx. 34), before beginning a moderate ascent towards 06/16/2024 (approx. 40).
*   **UI Element:** A three-line "hamburger" menu icon is visible in the top-right corner, indicating options or settings related to the chart display.
images.context: regated Risk Score over the selected date range.

images.alt:
This image displays a data visualization component, specifically a histogram or bar chart, set against a white background.

**Title and Context:**
The chart is titled **"Distribution of Users"** and includes a menu icon (three horizontal stacked lines) in the upper right corner, typical of an action or settings control for the visualization.

**Axes and Scaling:**
*   **Y-Axis (Vertical):** Labeled **"Number of Users"**. The scale ranges from 0 to 30, with major grid lines and labels at 10, 20, and 30.
*   **X-Axis (Horizontal):** Represents a score or category scale ranging from 0 to 95, labeled in increments of 5.

**Data Representation:**
The chart utilizes solid **blue** vertical bars to display the data distribution. The bars are grouped primarily in the center of the visible range:
1.  Concentrated data points are visible at scores 30, 35, 40, and 45.
2.  The peak concentration occurs at score 40, nearing 30 users.
3.  Minimal secondary data points are present at scores 55 and 60 (approximately 1 user each).

**Legend:**
A single legend entry is displayed below the X-axis: a blue marker followed by the text **"Risk Score Distribution"**.
images.context: Score ranges for the selected date range.

images.alt:
The image displays a data grid component used for security risk assessment, titled "Riskiest Users" with an accompanying dropdown chevron. The grid structure presents 10 columns, all of which are denoted as sortable by the inclusion of a bidirectional vertical arrow ($\uparrow$) icon in the header.

**Column Structure (Headers):**
The table tracks metrics across security domains:
1. User (Redacted)
2. Email Security
3. Endpoint Security
4. Data Security
5. Web Security
6. **Account Hygiene** (Header text is highlighted in red/maroon, suggesting a critical category)
7. Compliance Electives
8. Physical Security
9. **Risk Score** (Primary performance metric)
10. Trend

**Data Content and Styling:**
The data is sorted, likely by descending Risk Score, with the first two rows representing the highest risk profile.

*   **High Risk Data (Rows 1 & 2):** Metrics include an "Account Hygiene" score of 7.41 and a composite **Risk Score** of **51.63** (bolded and highlighted in red). The "Trend" column displays a red up-arrow ($\uparrow$) followed by the score (51.63), indicating an increase in risk.
*   **Lower Risk Data (Rows 3+):** Subsequent rows consistently display an "Account Hygiene" score of 4.46 and a **Risk Score** of **46.08** (bolded in black). The associated trend is "No change."

All security metrics (excluding Risk Score and Trend) are presented as two decimal numerical values.

This image displays a data table within a User Interface (UI) focused on team risk assessment, titled "Riskiest Teams" (blue text with a dropdown chevron).

**Table Structure (Columns):**

The table presents performance metrics across 10 sortable columns, indicated by up/down arrow icons ($\leftrightarrow$) next to the headers:

1.  **Manager:** (Team identification; data is blurred/redacted).
2.  **Email Security** (Score: 20.14)
3.  **Endpoint Security** (Score: 4.93)
4.  **Data Security** (Score: 5.42)
5.  **Web Security** (Score: 5.51)
6.  **Account Hygiene** (Score: 4.46)
7.  **Compliance Electives** (Score: 3.75)
8.  **Physical Security** (Score: 1.88)
9.  **Risk Score** (Aggregate score, bold text: **46.08**)
10. **Trend** (Status: "No change")

**Data Content:**

The table currently displays seven identical rows of numerical data, indicating that all listed teams (managers) share the same scores across all categories and have the same aggregate Risk Score (**46.08**) and Trend ("No change").

**Context:**

The UI appears to be a dashboard component used for monitoring and comparing security posture or risk metrics across organizational teams or groups, likely normalized to reflect relative weighting (totaling approximately 46.08).

This image displays a data grid used for security risk reporting, titled "Riskiest Groups" (with a corresponding blue chevron indicating a filter or dropdown menu).

**UI Structure and Elements:**

The interface is a tabular report featuring ten columns. All column headers are rendered in bold text and include a sort indicator (double-headed arrow $\updownarrow$), denoting that all columns are sortable.

**Column Headers and Data Context:**

The ten data metrics displayed in the header row are:
1.  **Group** (Data in this column is obscured/redacted.)
2.  **Email Security**
3.  **Endpoint Security**
4.  **Data Security**
5.  **Web Security**
6.  **Account Hygiene**
7.  **Compliance Electives**
8.  **Physical Security**
9.  **Risk Score** (The aggregated metric; scores are rendered in bold typeface.)
10. **Trend**

**Data Formatting:**

Scores across the security metric columns (2-8) are displayed as two-decimal numerical values (e.g., 20.14).

*   **Risk Score:** Multiple rows display a high score of **46.08**.
*   **Trend:** Most groups show the status "No change." The final visible row indicates a risk reduction: a score of **45.37** is paired with a Trend value showing a green downward arrow ($\downarrow$) and the numerical change `0.13`, signifying a decrease (improvement) in the risk score by 0.13 points.
